intro: Ischaemum indicum var. longipilum, commonly known as the long-hairy barnyard grass, is a perennial grass species native to warm temperate and tropical regions. It typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with slender, erect stems and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces small, spikelet-based inflorescences, which contain both male and female flowers, characteristic of the Poaceae family. Its leaves are often covered with long, stiff hairs, giving it its common name. This species is often found in disturbed soils and can be a weed in agricultural fields.
